The Elder’s Birth Story of the One Who Spread Out a Seat
“The supreme shrine,
of the one with a topknot, the friend of the world;

analyzed: araññe irīṇe vane  andhā ahiṇḍām aham tadā
translated: In the forest, in the wilderness, in the jungle,🔽I was wandering around blind.
When I came out of the forest,
I saw a lion throne;
Putting my upper robe over one shoulder,
I spread out a seat for the leader of the world.
Having spread out a seat for half a day,🔽for the Buddha, the leader of the world,

analyzed: haṭṭhaḥ haṭṭhena cittena  imam vācam udīrayi
translated: With a delighted mind,🔽I spoke this verse:
‘Homage to you, O Noble One,
homage to you, O Supreme One;
All-knowing one, great hero,
eldest in the world, bull among men.’
Having spread out a seat for the one with a topknot,
by making a sign,
I paid homage to the seat,
and departed facing north.
In the twenty-ninth eon from now,
the one I spread out a seat for, the best of speakers;
I do not know of any bad destination,
this is the fruit of spreading out a seat.
In the twenty-seventh eon from now,
seven incomparable ones appeared;
Endowed with the seven treasures,
wheel-turning monarchs of great strength.
The four discriminations,
I have done the Teacher’s bidding.”

original: Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā āsanasanthaviko thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.
